sn17.13-20:4.2: “Mendicants, when I’ve comprehended the mind of a certain person, I understand:
sn17.13-20:4.3: ‘This venerable would not tell a deliberate lie even for the sake of a gold coin.’ …
sn17.13-20:4.4: ‘… for the sake of a hundred gold coins.’ …
sn17.13-20:4.5: ‘… for the sake of a gold doubloon.’ …
sn17.13-20:4.6: ‘… for the sake of a hundred gold doubloons.’ …
sn17.13-20:4.7: ‘… for the sake of the whole earth full of gold.’ …
sn17.13-20:4.8: ‘… for any kind of material reward.’ …
sn17.13-20:4.10: ‘… for the sake of the finest lady in the land.’
sn17.13-20:4.11: But some time later I see them tell a deliberate lie because their mind is overcome and overwhelmed by possessions, honor, and popularity.
sn17.13-20:4.12: That’s how brutal, bitter, and harsh are possessions, honor, and popularity. …”
